message: After a two month IP "review", Tablib is back :)

GitHub Repo: https://github.com/kennethreitz/tablib
	Git Mirror: http://git.kennethreitz.com/projects/tablib
	Cheeseshop: http://pypi.python.org/pypi/tablib/0.9.5
	Cheeseshop Mirror (in case pypi is down): `pip install -i http://pip.kreitz.co/simple tablib`
	Convore Room: https://convore.com/tablib/
	Continuous Integration: http://ci.kennethreitz.com/job/tablib-tests/
Oh, and docs of course: http://tablib.org
didn't know it works over IP, too :)
Looks cool and on first glance the documentation is solid.  But was wondering if you could provide some use cases?
Is there any interoperability with Numpy's record arrays?
Looks great, Kenneth!  One note: you misspelled "Separators" in the docs: http://docs.tablib.org/en/latest/tutorial.html#seperators
@pwang there isn't, but I'd love to hear how you think that should work
A question: when is the dynamic column evaluated?
"data" should be "students" in the example at http://docs.tablib.org/en/latest/tutorial.html#filtering-datasets-with-tags

@kennethreitz Well, mostly just a set of .from_numpy() and .to_numpy() methods, really.  You'd have to do some inference about the types of columns (or offer auto-inference as an optional argument to the to_numpy() method) so you could construct the proper Numpy dtype.  But it doesn't *seem* to be that difficult, at first glance.

@pwang I've created a new issue for this. It's something that I've been pondering for a while, but haven't spent the time to figure out the best approach. Would you mind adding your notes to the issue?
